summary: This is an academic journal article by former FBI agent Kenneth Lanning, published in the Journal of Interpersonal Violence in 2017. It traces the historical evolution of the concept and term 'grooming' as used in the context of child sexual exploitation, detailing its origins in law enforcement discussions in the late 1970s and its gradual replacement of the term 'seduction'. This document is an academic article from the Journal of Interpersonal Violence, authored by Kenneth Lanning, discussing the concept of 'grooming' in child sexual exploitation cases. It provides a detailed analysis of grooming techniques, challenges in distinguishing grooming from mentoring, and the legal and psychological considerations regarding child victims. The article references multiple seminars and publications on the topic.

persons.name: Kenneth Lanning
persons.role: Author, former FBI agent and consultant
persons.context: Author of the article, a former FBI agent who helped develop the concept of grooming/seduction in child exploitation cases. He details his experience from 1973-2017.

persons.name: Nicholas Groth
persons.context: Cited as an early expert in the field of child sexual abuse. His 1979 book provided an early description of what later became known as the grooming process.

persons.name: Susan Sgroi
persons.context: Cited as an early expert in the field of child sexual abuse during the growing recognition of intrafamilial cases in the 1970s/80s.

persons.name: Roland Summit
persons.context: Cited as an early expert in the field. He developed the 'Child Sexual Abuse Accommodation Syndrome' in the early 1980s.

persons.name: Jon Conte
persons.context: Cited as an early expert in the field. His 1984 article is noted as potentially the first published naming of the process as 'grooming'.

persons.name: David Finkelhor
persons.context: Cited as an early expert/scholar in the field of child sexual abuse during the 1970s/80s.

persons.name: Park E. Dietz
persons.context: Cited for a 1983 observation about paraphiliacs gravitating to jobs/hobbies that provide exposure to their preferred imagery. Co-author with Lanning on a 2014 publication.

persons.name: Lloyd Martin
persons.context: Former detective sergeant with the LAPD's Sexually Exploited Child Unit. Co-authored a 1982 book detailing the seduction process used by acquaintance molesters.

persons.name: Ann Wolbert Burgess
persons.context: Co-author with Kenneth Lanning on a 1984 article in the FBI Law Enforcement Bulletin discussing offender seduction techniques.

persons.name: P. E. Dietz
persons.context: Co-authored a 2014 article with Lanning on acquaintance child molesters and youth-serving organizations; referenced for work on sex offenses.

persons.name: A. W. Burgess
persons.context: Co-authored a 1984 article with Lanning on child pornography and sex rings.

persons.name: S. L. Goldstein
persons.context: Cited for publications on investigating child sexual exploitation and the sexual exploitation of children.

persons.name: A. N. Groth
persons.context: Co-authored 'Men who rape: The psychology of the offender' (1979), referenced in the bibliography.

persons.name: H. J. Birnbaum
persons.context: Co-authored 'Men who rape: The psychology of the offender' (1979) with A. N. Groth.

persons.name: R. C. Summit
persons.context: Cited for developing 'The child sexual abuse accommodation syndrome' (1983).

persons.name: C. van Dam
persons.context: Cited for work on 'The socially skilled child molester' (2006).

connections.description: Co-authored a 2014 publication referenced in the article about offenders gravitating to youth-serving organizations.
Co-authored a 1984 article in the FBI Law Enforcement Bulletin discussing how offenders gain control of victims through seduction.
Both were law enforcement professionals specializing in and helping to formalize concepts around the sexual exploitation of children during the same period (1980s).
Co-authored the 2014 article 'Acquaintance child molesters and youth-serving organizations' referenced in this document.
Co-authored the 1984 article 'Child pornography and sex rings' referenced in the bibliography.
Co-authored the 1979 book 'Men who rape: The psychology of the offender' referenced in the bibliography.

events.title: Groth's book describes grooming process
events.description: Nicholas Groth publishes a book that clearly describes what later becomes known as the grooming process, though he does not use the term.

events.title: Illinois Legislative Report
events.description: The Illinois Legislative Investigating Commission submits a report noting patterns of child molesters becoming involved in legitimate youth groups to gain access to children.

events.title: Martin co-authors book on exploitation
events.description: Lloyd Martin co-authors a book focusing on sexual exploitation of children cases, detailing the seduction process with case examples.

events.title: Conte article names 'grooming' process
events.description: Jon Conte publishes an article that footnotes the description of the 'grooming process' to Groth's 1979 book, potentially providing the first published naming of the process as grooming.

events.title: FBI Bulletin 'Pedophilia' issue
events.description: The FBI Law Enforcement Bulletin publishes a special issue on 'Pedophilia,' containing articles by Lanning and others discussing offenders gaining access through occupation/vocation and using seduction.

events.title: Lanning's FBI monograph on typology
events.description: The FBI disseminates a free monograph authored by Kenneth Lanning setting forth his typology of child molesters, including the 'Seduction Type'.

events.title: Lanning uses 'grooming' in writing
events.description: Kenneth Lanning uses the term 'grooming' in writing for the first time in an NCMEC publication titled 'Child Sex Rings: A Behavioral Analysis', describing it as part of the seduction process.

events.title: FBI seminars at Quantico
events.description: Kenneth Lanning, at the FBI Behavioral Science Unit, brings together investigators specializing in extrafamilial sexual exploitation cases at seminars in Quantico, VA, to discuss and formalize concepts of seduction and grooming.

events.title: Advanced Seminar on Sexual Exploitation of Children
events.description: Seminar sponsored by the Federal Bureau of Investigation held at the Xerox Training Center in Leesburg, Virginia.

events.title: Dallas Child Sexual Exploitation Seminar
events.description: Seminar sponsored by the Dallas Police Department held in Dallas, Texas.

events.title: National Law Enforcement Seminar on Sexual Exploitation of Children
events.description: Seminar sponsored by the Federal Bureau of Investigation held at the FBI Academy in Quantico, Virginia.

events.title: Sexual Exploitation of Children Seminar
events.description: Seminar sponsored by the Federal Bureau of Investigation held at the FBI Academy in Quantico, Virginia.

events.title: Protecting Our Children: The Fight Against Molestation Symposium
events.description: A national symposium held in Washington, DC, sponsored by the U.S. Department of Justice.

keyFacts: The term 'grooming' in the context of child sexual exploitation originated among a group of law enforcement investigators in the late 1970s to describe a seduction pattern of offender behavior.
The concept emerged with the growing recognition of extrafamilial acquaintance offenders in the 1980s, as law enforcement moved beyond focusing solely on 'stranger danger' and intrafamilial abuse.
Early literature and experts like Nicholas Groth (1979) described the process, but Jon Conte's 1984 article is noted as potentially the first to name it 'grooming' in publication.
Kenneth Lanning, the author, first used the term 'grooming' in writing in a 1989 NCMEC publication, though he personally prefers the term 'seduction' for its clarity.

The article clarifies that grooming/seduction refers to specific nonviolent techniques (attention, affection, gifts, privileges) used to gain access and control, and is generally incompatible with the use of force or threats.
The article defines grooming as a non-violent process used by sex offenders to access and control child victims, which can itself constitute sexual gratification and be a sex offense.
It argues that child victims should be considered victims under the law simply due to their age and developmental immaturity, regardless of whether force, threats, or violence were used.
The document highlights the difficulty for youth-serving organizations in distinguishing grooming behavior from legitimate mentoring activities.
It references multiple FBI-sponsored seminars and law enforcement publications on child sexual exploitation dating from the 1980s, indicating long-standing institutional focus on the issue.
Author Kenneth Lanning is identified as a former FBI special agent with over 30 years of experience, specializing in behavioral analysis of crimes against children.
